astilbe.description: Known for its beautiful, plume-like flowers that rise above ferny foliage, Astilbe is a shade-loving perennial that adds a soft texture to gardens.
astilbe.fun_fact: Despite its delicate appearance, Astilbe is a surprisingly robust plant and is resistant to most pests and deer.

bellflower.description: Characterized by its charming, bell-shaped flowers, this plant comes in various forms, from low-growing ground covers to tall, stately spikes.
bellflower.fun_fact: The name 'Campanula', its genus, is Latin for 'little bell'.

black_eyed_susan.description: A cheerful, native North American wildflower with golden-yellow, daisy-like petals and a prominent dark brown center.
black_eyed_susan.fun_fact: It is the state flower of Maryland and is known for attracting a wide variety of pollinators.

calendula.description: An annual flower with bright orange or yellow petals. It is widely cultivated and known for its use in herbal remedies and as a culinary ingredient.
calendula.fun_fact: The petals are edible and can be used in salads or as a saffron substitute to color rice.

california_poppy.description: A vibrant orange wildflower native to the United States and Mexico. Its silky petals close at night or in cold, windy weather.
california_poppy.fun_fact: It is the official state flower of California and was selected in 1890, beating the Mariposa Lily and the Poinsettia.

carnation.description: A popular flower with ruffled, fragrant petals and a long blooming period. Carnations are available in a vast array of colors, each with its own symbolism.
carnation.fun_fact: The scientific name, Dianthus, comes from Greek and translates to 'flower of the gods'.

common_daisy.description: A familiar European species of daisy, often considered a weed in lawns but beloved for its simple white petals and bright yellow center.
common_daisy.fun_fact: The name 'daisy' is believed to come from the Old English 'dæges ēage', meaning 'day's eye', because the petals open at dawn and close at dusk.

coreopsis.description: A bright and sunny flower, Coreopsis is known for its long blooming season and tolerance to a wide range of soil conditions.
coreopsis.fun_fact: It gets its common name 'tickseed' because its small, dark seeds resemble ticks.

daffodil.description: One of the first signs of spring, daffodils are known for their trumpet-shaped central corona surrounded by a ring of petals.
daffodil.fun_fact: Giving daffodils as a gift is believed to bring good fortune, but be sure to give a bunch, as a single daffodil can signify misfortune.

dandelion.description: Often seen as a common weed, this plant is entirely edible, from its yellow flower petals to its leaves and roots. Known for its iconic 'puffball' seed head.
dandelion.bloom_season: Mainly Spring, but can occur year-round
dandelion.fun_fact: The dandelion is a rich source of vitamins A, C, and K, and its greens can be used in salads.

iris.description: Named after the Greek goddess of the rainbow, the Iris flower is known for its elegant, ornate, and colorful blooms with three large outer petals and three inner upright petals.
iris.fun_fact: The fleur-de-lis, a stylized lily or iris, is a symbol that has been used for centuries by French royalty.

magnolia.description: An ancient species, magnolias are known for their large, fragrant, and beautiful flowers that can be white, pink, purple, or yellow. They bloom before the leaves appear.
magnolia.fun_fact: Magnolias evolved before bees appeared, so their flowers are designed to be pollinated by beetles.

rose.description: A woody perennial flowering plant, the rose is perhaps the most famous flower in the world, celebrated for its beauty, fragrance, and symbolism of love.
rose.fun_fact: The world's oldest living rose is believed to be 1,000 years old. It grows on a wall of the Hildesheim Cathedral in Germany.

sunflower.description: A tall annual plant with a large, bright yellow flower head. Sunflowers are known for heliotropism, where young flowers follow the sun across the sky.
sunflower.fun_fact: A single sunflower head can contain up to 2,000 seeds, which are a source of oil and a popular snack.

tulip.description: A spring-blooming perennial with bold, cup-shaped flowers. Tulips are native to Central Asia but are famously associated with the Netherlands.
tulip.fun_fact: During the 17th century, 'Tulip Mania' in the Netherlands caused the price of a single tulip bulb to skyrocket to more than the cost of a house.

water_lily.description: An aquatic plant with large, floating leaves and beautiful, star-shaped flowers that rise above the water. It is a symbol of purity in many cultures.
water_lily.fun_fact: The national flower of India is the Lotus, which is often confused with the Water Lily, but they belong to different families.
